metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C++ Maps
C++ Map
A map stores elements in " key/value " pairs.
content.html: A map stores elements in "key/value" pairs.

content.text: Elements in a map are:
content.html: Elements in a map are:

content.text: To use a map, you have to include the <map> header file:
content.html: To use a map, you have to include the <map> header file:

content.code_html:
// Include the map library
#include <map>

content.text: Create a Map

To create a map, use the map keyword, and specify the type of both the key and the value it should store within angle brackets <> . At last, specify the name of the map, like: map < keytype, valuetype > mapName :
content.html: To create a map, use the map keyword, and specify the type of both the key and the value it should store within angle brackets <>. At last, specify the name of the map, like: map<keytype, valuetype> mapName:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a 
  map called people that will store strings as keys and integers as values

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a 
  map called people that will store strings as keys and integers as values

content.code_html:
// Create a map called people that will store strings as keys and integers as values
 map<string, int> people

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a 
  map called people that will store strings as keys and integers as values

content.text: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {} :
content.html: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {}:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a 
  map that will store the name and age of different people

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a 
  map that will store the name and age of different people

content.code_html:
// Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
 map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a 
  map that will store the name and age of different people

content.text: Access a Map
You cannot access map elements by referring to index numbers, like you would with arrays and vectors .
content.html: You cannot access map elements by referring to index numbers, like you would with arrays and vectors.

content.text: Instead, you can access a map element by referring to its key inside square brackets [] :
content.html: Instead, you can access a map element by referring to its key inside square brackets []:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
// Get the value associated with the key "John"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Adele"

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
// Get the value associated with the key "John"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Adele"

content.code_html:
// Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
 map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Get the value associated with the key "John"
cout << "John is: " << people["John"] << "\n";

// Get the value associated with the key "Adele"
cout << "Adele is: " << people["Adele"] << "\n";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
// Get the value associated with the key "John"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Adele"

content.text: You can also access elements with the .at() function:
content.html: You can also access elements with the .at() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

// 
  Get the value associated with the key "Adele"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Bo"

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

// 
  Get the value associated with the key "Adele"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Bo"

content.code_html:
// Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
 map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

 // Get the value associated with the key "Adele"
cout << "Adele is: " << people.at("Adele") << "\n";

// Get the value associated with the key "Bo"
cout << "Bo is: " << people.at("Bo") << "\n";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

// 
  Get the value associated with the key "Adele"

// Get the value associated with the key 
  "Bo"

content.text: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it throws an error message if the element does not exist:
content.html: Note: The .at() function is often preferred over square brackets [] because it throws an error message if the element does not exist:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

content.code_html:
// Create a map that will store the name and age of different people
 map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Try to access an element that does not exist (will throw an exception)
cout << people.at("Jenny");

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a map that will store the name and age of different people

content.text: Change Values
You can also change the value associated with a key:
content.html: You can also change the value associated with a key:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Change John's value to 50 instead of 32
people["John"] = 50;

cout << "John is: " << people["John"];  // Now outputs John is: 50

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

content.text: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:
content.html: However, it is safer to use the .at() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

syntax_highlighting.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Change John's value to 50 instead of 32
people.at("John") = 50;

cout << "John is: " << people.at("John");  // Now outputs John is: 50

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Change John's value to 50 instead of 32

content.text: Add Elements
To add elements to a map, it is ok to use square brackets [] :
content.html: To add elements to a map, it is ok to use square brackets []:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Add new elements
 people["Jenny"] = 22;
people["Liam"] = 24;
people["Kasper"] = 20;
people["Anja"] = 30;

content.text: But you can also use the .insert() function:
content.html: But you can also use the .insert() function:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Add new elements
people.insert({"Jenny", 22});
people.insert({"Liam", 24});
people.insert({"Kasper", 20});
people.insert({"Anja", 30});

content.text: Elements with Equal Keys
A map cannot have elements with equal keys.
content.html: A map cannot have elements with equal keys.

content.text: For example, if we try to add "Jenny" two times to the map, it will only keep the first one:
content.html: For example, if we try to add "Jenny" two times to the map, it will only keep the first one:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Trying to add two elements with equal keys

syntax_highlighting.text: // Trying to add two elements with equal keys

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Trying to add two elements with equal keys
people.insert({"Jenny", 22});
people.insert({"Jenny", 30});

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Trying to add two elements with equal keys

content.text: To sum up; values can be equal, but keys must be unique.
content.html: To sum up; values can be equal, but keys must be unique.

content.text: Remove Elements
To remove specific elements from a map, you can use the .erase() function:
content.html: To remove specific elements from a map, you can use the .erase() function:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Remove an element by key
 people.erase("John");

content.text: To remove all elements from a map, you can use the .clear() function:
content.html: To remove all elements from a map, you can use the .clear() function:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

// Remove all elements
 people.clear();

content.text: Find the Size of a Map
To find out how many elements a map has, use the .size() function:
content.html: To find out how many elements a map has, use the .size() function:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };
cout << people.size();  // Outputs 3

content.text: Check if a Map is Empty
Use the .empty() function to find out if a map is empty or not.
content.html: Use the .empty() function to find out if a map is empty or not.

content.text: The .empty() function returns 1 ( true ) if the map is empty and 0 ( false ) otherwise:
content.html: The .empty() function returns 1 (true) if the map is empty and 0 (false) otherwise:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
map<string, int> people;cout << people.empty(); 
  // Outputs 1 (The map is empty)

content.code:
map<string, int> people;cout << people.empty();
// Outputs 1 (The map is empty)

syntax_highlighting.text:
map<string, int> people;cout << people.empty(); 
 // Outputs 1 (The map is empty)

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people;
cout << people.empty(); // Outputs 1 (The map is empty)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
map<string, int> people;cout << people.empty(); 
  // Outputs 1 (The map is empty)

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };
cout << people.empty();  // Outputs 0 (not empty)

content.text: Note: You can also check if a specific element exists, by using the .count( key ) function.
content.html: Note: You can also check if a specific element exists, by using the .count(key) function.

content.text: It returns 1 ( true ) if the element exists and 0 ( false ) otherwise:
content.html: It returns 1 (true) if the element exists and 0 (false) otherwise:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };
cout << people.count("John");  // Outputs 1 (John exists)

content.text: Loop Through a Map
You can loop through a map with the for-each loop. However, there are a couple of things to be aware of:
content.html: You can loop through a map with the for-each loop. However, there are a couple of things to be aware of:

content.code_html:
map<string, int> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

for (auto person : people) {
  cout << person.first << " is: " << person.second << "\n";
}

content.text: If you want to reverse the order, you can use the greater < type > functor inside the angle brackets, like this:
content.html: If you want to reverse the order, you can use the greater<type> functor inside the angle brackets, like this:

content.code_html:
map<string, int, greater<string>> people = { {"John", 32}, {"Adele", 45}, {"Bo", 29} };

for (auto person : people) {
  cout << person.first << " is: " << person.second << "\n";
}

content.text: Tip: It is also possible to loop through maps with an iterator , which you will learn more about in the next chapter.
content.html: Tip: It is also possible to loop through maps with an iterator, which you will learn more about in the next chapter.

What is the primary characteristic of a map in C++?
content.html: What is the primary characteristic of a map in C++?

metadata.question: What is the primary characteristic of a map in C++?

options.text: Stores elements in key/value pairs with unique keys
Stores elements in a random order

Stores elements in a random order
